means: 脑筋转不过来的，旧思想的

sentence.Network_en: She accused him of being an unreconstructed male chauvinist.
sentence.Network_cn: 她指责他是一个顽固不化的大男子主义者。

sentence.Network_en: There are probably more unreconstructed southerners than one would like to admit.
sentence.Network_cn: 或许守旧的南方人数量比人们乐于承认的数字还要大.

sentence.Network_en: Mr Prescott's punch reminded voters that he was irascible and unreconstructed.
sentence.Network_cn: 普雷斯科特的对打,提醒了选民他脾气暴躁思想古板.

PerfectNetExp.abs: unrecognized 未被认识的unreconstructed 脑筋转不过来的unredeemable 不能收回的
unreasonable 不合理的unreconstructed 顽固守旧的unrefined 粗俗的
It is full of new unreconstructed collision , conflict and argue ., 它布满着新旧思想的碰撞 , 冲突和较量.
...defiant 挑衅的；目中无人的；蔑视的；挑战的unreconstructed 旧思想的；脑筋转不过来的a hint of 少许，一点点

Most of the party thinks the Tories are unreconstructed Thatcherites ., 大多数的工党成员认为保守党是脑筋僵硬的撒切尔夫人支持者.
It is full of new unreconstructed collision , conflict and argue ., 它布满着新旧思想的碰撞 , 冲突和较量.

example.ex: If you describe systems, beliefs, policies, or people as unreconstructed, you are critical of them because they have not changed at all, in spite of new ideas and circumstances.
example.tran: 一成不变的；墨守成规的

example.ex: ...the unreconstructed racism of the official opposition...
example.tran: 官方反对顽固守旧的种族主义思想

means.word_mean: 1. adhering to an attitude or position widely held to be outmoded;

sentences.sentence: "peasants are still unreconstructed small capitalists at heart"
"there are probably more unreconstructed Southerners than one would like to admit"

auth_sentence.content: These tracks are perfect slices of unreconstructed rock; evidence that Pearl Jam never lost the art of penning memorable tunes.

auth_sentence.content: Kelly comes across as every inch the unreconstructed lover, with Your Body's Callin' establishing the pattern of the album.

auth_sentence.res_content_con: Kelly comes across as every inch the unreconstructed lover, with Your Body's Callin' establishing the pattern of the album.

auth_sentence.content: These, the rent-a-quotes from the unreconstructed fringe, are the new grasshoppers of British politics.
